questions.text: An elderly patient with renal impairment has overactive bladder. Which of the following drug needs dose adjustment in order to be used in the above patient?
questions.solution:
Trospium is the only antimuscarininc agent used in overactive bladder that is eliminated primarily by kidneys

Over 60% of absorbed drug is eliminated unchanged by kidneys

Dose adjustments are essential in patients with impaired renal function

Solifenacin and oxybutynin are primarily metabolized by CYP3A4 whereas tolterodine is metabolized by both CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 (options a, b and d)

questions.text: Cholinergic synapses occur at
questions.solution:
Cholinergic synapses location

  • Autonomic effector sites innervated by postganglionic parasympathetic nerves
  • Sweat glands innervated by postganglionic sympathetic nerves
  • Sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia and the adrenal medulla, innervated by preganglionic autonomic nerves
  • Motor end plates on skeletal muscle, innervated by somatic motor nerves
  • Certain synapses in the CNS where acetylcholine can have either pre- or postsynaptic action

questions.text: Malathion is indicated clinically for topical treatment of
questions.solution:
Malathion is used for pediculosis capitis in cases of permethrin resistance

Malathion has low toxicity in mammalian species. It can be detoxified by plasma carboxylesterase.

The detoxification reaction is more rapid in mammals and birds than insects.

 

Note: Malathion 0.5% topical solution is used as a treatment of classic scabies when permethrin is ineffective.

questions.text: Mivacurium has a short duration of action due to its rapid metabolism by
questions.solution:
Mivacurium is extremely sensitive to catalysis by plasma cholinesterase and other hydrolases that accounts for its short duration of action.

Atracurium and cistracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination along with plasma hydrolysis (option a).

questions.text: Alpha 1A selective receptor antagonist among the following is?
questions.solution:
Silodosin exhibits selectivity over alpha 1A (α1A) receptors than alpha 1B (α1B) receptors.

Tamsulosin is the other alpha 1A selective blocker.

Alpha 1A selective blockers

  • Lesser incidence of dizziness and changes in blood pressure
  • Higher incidence of abnormal ejaculation (retrograde ejaculation)

questions.text: Beta-blocker having potassium channel opening action
questions.solution:
Tilisolol is a third-generation non-selective beta-blocker having an additional action of opening the potassium channels.

Additional activities of 3rd generation beta-blockers:

  • α1 adrenergic receptor blockade: labetalol, carvedilol, bucindolol, bevantolol, nipradilol
  • Increased production of NO: celiprolol, nebivolol, carteolol, bopindolol, nipradolol
  • β2 agonist properties: celiprolol, carteolol, bopindolol
  • Ca2+ entry blockade: carvedilol, betaxolol, bevantolol
  • Opening of K+ channels: tilisolol
  • Antioxidant action: carvedilol

questions.text: Highly sedative antihistamine among the following is
questions.solution:
Promethazine is a highly sedative first generation antihistamine.

Chlorpheniramine maleate is also a first generation antihistamine but it has mild sedative action (option a).

Cetirizine and levocetirizine are second generation antihistamine with very minimal/no sedative action (options c and d).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about acetyl salicylic acid?

choices.text: Clearance is independent of plasma concentration
Antiplatelet action is related to pre-systemic COX inhibition

questions.solution:
Acetyl salicylic acid is the chemical name of aspirin.

  • Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme in the portal circulation(pre systemic) and deactivates it before aspirin is deacetylated in the liver
  • Aspirin is an irreversible inhibitor of the COX (cyclooxygenase enzyme) (option a)
  • Aspirin has no inhibitory effects on lipoxygenase (option d)
  • Aspirin shows saturation kinetics; at lower plasma concentration aspirin shows first order kinetics and the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration, whereas at higher plasma concentration zero order kinetics can be seen (option b)

questions.text: Mechanism of action of nicorandil in angina is/are
questions.solution:
Nicorandil has both nitrate-like (c-GMP dependent) properties and acts as an agonist of ATP-sensitive potassium channels.

Vasodilating action of nicorandil is potentiated by PDE5 inhibitors and only partially blocked by inhibitors of potassium sensitive ATP channels suggesting that both mechanisms is relevant for its action.

questions.text: Metolazone belongs to the following class of diuretics
questions.solution:
Metolazone is a thiazide-like diuretic.

Points to note about metolazone:

  • Unlike other diuretics, the antihypertensive and diuretic action of metolazone is retained even in severe renal failure (GFR <15 ml/min).
  • Additional proximal tubular action has been observed.

questions.text: The following beta blocker used in arrhythmias has additional class I action
questions.solution:
Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker with additional membrane stabilising action especially at higher doses: Na+ channel blockade/ class I action. 

Sotalol is a non-selective beta blocker with prominent class III action: K+ channel blockade (option a).

Esmolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that does not have any additional class effect (option b).

questions.text: Which of the following ACE inhibitor is a prodrug ?
questions.solution:
Fosinopril is a prodrug that is converted to its active form fosinoprilat.

Enalaprilat is the active form of enalapril (option b).

Lisinopril is the active lysine derivative of enalapril (option c). Captopril is also an active drug (option d).

questions.text: Which of the following is microsomal triglyceride transfer inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Lomitapide belongs to a new class of microsomal triglyceride transfer inhibitor.

Microsomal triglyceride transferm protein (MTP) is essential for the synthesis of VLDL.

Lomitapide is approved for use in homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia.

Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor (option a).

Saroglitazar is a dual PPAR inhibitor (option c).

Acipimox is a nicotinic acid derivative (option d).

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you were asked to name a calcium sensitizer used in the management of a patient with acute decompensated heart failure. Which of the following drugs would you mention?
questions.solution:
Levosimendan is a myofilament calcium sensitizer used in the short-term management of acute decompensated heart failure.

It increases the sensitivity of contractile myofilaments to Calcium by binding and inducing a conformational change in thin-filament regulatory protein troponin-C.

It increases cardiac output and decreases vascular resistance (ionodilator). Other actions like inhibition of phosphodiesterases, opening of potassium channels, and inhibition of pro-inflammatory cytokines are observed.

Other options :

Option B and C: Milrinone and enoximone are PDE-3 inhibitors indicated in acute decompensated heart failure

Option D: Cinacalcet is a calcium sensitizer that increases the sensitivity of calcium sensing receptor to extracellular calcium in parathyroid glands. It is used to reduce serum calcium levels primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: All of the following are short acting insulin analogs except
questions.solution:
Glargine is a long acting peakless insulin.

Short acting insulin analogs

  • Lispro
  • Aspart
  • Glulisine

questions.text: Half life of liothyronine (T3) is
questions.solution:
Liothyronine is short acting (t1/2~1 day) when compared to levothyroxine (t1/2 ~ 7 days).

Liothyronine has to be administered three times per day whereas levothyroxine can be administered once daily.

Liothyronine (T3) is the more active form of thyroid hormone and has a rapid onset of action. It is indicated in conditions where rapid action is preferred like rare cases of myxedema coma.

Note: The earlier version of Goodman and Gillman (12th edition: 1143) mentioned the plasma half life to be around 0.75 days. Some of the journals do reflect the same. 

But the recent version of both Goodman and Gillman and Katzung mentions the half life to be around 1 day. The journal mentioned in the reference also mentions that the half life is around 1 day for euthyroid patients and we think the most appropriate answer is 1 day.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding plasma calcium ?

choices.text: Most of the unionized calcium is bound to albumin

questions.solution:
Ionized form of calcium is physiologically important.

Normal calcium level in plasma is 9-11 mg/dl (option a).

40% of calcium is bound to plasma albumin (option c). 10 % is bound to citrate, phosphate and carbonate.

Remaining 50% is in ionized form and is physiologically important. Acidosis favours ionization of calcium whereas alkalosis favours deionization of calcium (option d).

Clinical correlate:

  • Hyperventilation by causing alkalosis favours deionization of calcium.
  • Can result in precipitation of tetany and laryngospasm in calcium deficient pateints

questions.text: Which of the following is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor ?
questions.solution:
Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor indicated in Benign prostatic hypertrophy and female hirsutism.

Flutamide is an antiandrogen (option a).

Methyltestosterone is 17 alpha methylated derivative of testosterone (option c).

questions.text: Which of the following accurately represents the action of glucocorticoids on the function of osteoblasts and osteoclasts?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids inhibit osteoblasts and stimulate osteoclasts resulting in the development of osteoporosis.

Other causes of osteoporosis by corticosteroids:

  • Inhibition of gonadal steroidal hormones
  • Reduced gastrointestinal absorption of calcium
  • The secondary effect of decreased calcium absorption: increased parathyroid hormone leading to further resorption

The ribs and the vertebrae are the most frequent sites of fracture

questions.text: The primary mechanism of action of the emergency contraceptive ulipristal is
questions.solution:
Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator. The most relevant action is inhibition of ovulation due to its progesterone regulation action at many levels including inhibition of LH release from hypothalamus.

Antiproliferative effects on uterus are seen only at higher doses (option d).

It has no/minimal activity on tubal motility and no spermicidal activity (option a and b).

questions.text: Which of the following is an intravenous induction anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Etomidate is an intravenous induction anesthetic agent.

Enflurane, nitrous oxide and xenon are inhalational induction anesthetic agents.

Intravenous induction agents

  • Thiopental
  • Methohexital
  • Ketamine
  • Propofol
  • Etomidate

questions.text: Hyponatremia risk is highest with the following antiepileptic drug
questions.solution:
Oxcarbazepine is a keto analog of carbamazepine and has a higher risk of hyponatremia than carbamazepine.

Carbamazepine potentiates ADH action and can cause hyponatremia and water retention especially in elderly people.

Unlike carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine does not cause autoinduction of hepatic CYP enzymes and is also a less potent inducer of hepatic metabolizing enzymes.

questions.text: Atypical antipsychotic with least risk of galactorrhoea is
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole has almost no risk of galactorrhoea. The adverse effect corresponds to their higher D2 blocking potency.

Galactorrhoea risk stratification for atypical antipsychotics

High risk:

  • Respiridone (option b)
  • Paliperidone

Limited risk:

  • Asenapine
  • Ilaperidone (option a)
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine (option c)
  • Ziprasidone

Almost no risk:

  • Clozapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Brexpiprazole
  • Cariprazine

questions.text: Transdermal preparation of the following agent is available for use in Parkinson’s disease
questions.solution:
Rotigotine is a dopamine receptor agonist that is available as transdermal preparation for use in Parkinson’s disease.

Ropinirole and pramipexole are dopamine receptor agonists but are not available as transdermal preparation (options a and c).

Selegiline is a MAO-B inhibitor that is available as a transdermal patch but the transdermal preparation is indicated only in major depression (option d).

questions.text: Orexin receptor antagonist indicated for insomnia is
questions.solution:
Suvorexant is the orexin receptor antagonist that is approved for use in insomnia. Orexins promote wakefulness and antagonists of orexin receptor induces sleep.

Aprepitant, rolaprepitant and netupitant are NK1 receptor antagonist used as antiemetics (options a, b and d).

questions.text: Megaloblastic anemia is caused by deficiency of
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anemia can occur in the deficiency of either Vitamin B9 (folic acid) and/or vitamin B12 (cobalamin).

Vitamin C deficiency is associated with scurvy.

Clinical correlate: In undiagnosed megaloblastic anemia, folic acid should not be prescribed alone without vitamin B12 supplementation.

Folic acid alone causes improvement of anemic symptoms as higher doses of folic acid will circumvent the methylfolate trap (option c).

But neurological dysfunction may occur or progress if already present due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

The meagre amount of vitamin B12 present is also diverted to hematopoesis if only folic acid is administered.

questions.text: Protamine sulfate is an antidote for
questions.solution:
Protamine sulfate is a mixture of basic polypeptides isolated from salmon sperm. It is indicated for reversal of heparin overdose.

It binds acidic heparin with high affinity and neutralises the anticoagulant activity. The resultant protamine-heparin complexes are cleared.

Vitamin K is used in warfarin overdose (options a and c).

Idarucizumab is an antidote for dabigatran (option d).

questions.text: Vorapaxar is a newer antiplatelet agent that has the following mechanism of action
questions.solution:
Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease activated receptor-1 (PAR-1).

It inhibits thrombin platelet aggregation.

questions.text: Which of the following does not activate plasminogen bound to fibrin preferentially?
questions.solution:
Anistreplase is a preformed complex of plasminogen and streptokinase that is acylated to protect the active sites. It does not activate plasminogen bound to fibrin preferentially.

Plasminogen activators (fibrinolytics classification)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase
  • Tenecteplase
  • Reteplase

questions.text: GLP-2 receptor agonist among the following is
questions.solution:
Teduglutide is a GLP-2 receptor agonist indicated for use in short bowel syndrome. It is an intestinotrophic gut peptide that enhances the growth of intestinal mucosa through release of mediators.

Liraglutide and albiglutide are GLP-1 receptor agonist indicated in the management of diabetes mellitus (options a and b).

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody against IL 5 indicated for the treatment in severe asthma is
questions.solution:
Mepolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-5 that is indicated as an add-on to maintenance therapy in severe asthma with eosinophilic phenotype.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE (option a).

Lebrikizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-13 (option c).

questions.text: Ipratropium bromide belongs to the following class
questions.solution: Ipratropium bromide is a muscarinic antagonist that is indicated as an inhalational agent in COPD and asthma.

questions.text: A pregnant woman who was in preterm labor was infused with an oxytocin receptor antagonist. Which of the following drugs was she likely administered?
questions.solution:
The oxytocin receptor antagonist that would have likely been administered to her is the tocolytic atosiban.

Tocolytics are drugs that suppress uterine contractions of preterm labor. Atosiban acts as an oxytocin receptor antagonist and inhibits preterm labor at 24-33 weeks of gestation.

Tocolytics can be effective only if administered before cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm and the lower uterine segment is taken up minimally. Other tocolytics that are used to delay premature labor:

  • Beta-2 agonists - ritodrine, terbutaline, isoxsuprine
  • Calcium channel blockers - nifedipine
  • Magnesium sulfate - It is a tocolytic as well as a first-line drug that is used in pre-eclampsia and eclampsia. 
  • Indomethacin

Related Pearl: Tocolytic agents

Drugs Examples
Calcium channel blockers
Nifedipine
Nicardipine
Verapamil
Competitive inhibition to calcium ion
 Magnesium sulfate
Cyclo-oxygenase inhibitors
Indomethacin
Sulindac
Beta mimetics
Terbutaline
Ritodrine
Isoxsuprine
Oxytocin Antagonists
Atosiban
Nitric oxide (NO) Donors
  Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN)

questions.text: Which of the following is a H2 receptor blocker?
questions.solution:
Cimetidine is a H2 receptor blocker indicated in acid peptic disorders.

Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (option a).

Cetirizine and levocetirizine are second generation H1 receptor blockers (options b and c).

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the antidiarrheal agent racecadotril is
questions.solution:
Racecadotril is a peripheral enkephalinase inhibitor.

Enkephalins are delta-opioid receptor agonists that decrease secretions. Racecadotril acts as an antisecretory agent by increasing enkephalin levels. It has minimal/no effect on motility.

Racecadotril is indicated for symptomatic treatment of diarrhea in infants and children.

questions.text: Tenofovir belongs to the following class
questions.solution:
Tenofovir is a derivative of adenosine monophosphate and is considered as a nucleotide analog.

Therefore, tenofovir is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor.

questions.text: Which of the following antimalarial agent is a fast acting schizonticide ?
questions.solution:
Pyrimethamine is a slow acting schizonticide (option b).

Mefloquine and quinine are intermediate acting schizonticide (options a and c).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a bactericidal agent ?
questions.solution:
Chloramphenicol acts by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis and is generally considered as a bacteriostatic agent.

Cotrimoxazole is bactericidal due to the sequential blockade on bacterial folate synthesis (option a).

Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) are bactericidal agents (option c).

Cefotetan is a cephalosporin that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis resulting in bactericidal action (option d).

questions.text: Alkalinisation of urine for overdose of acidic drugs is usually done by the following agent
questions.solution:
Alkalinisation of urine is done by infusing sodium bicarbonate in 5% dextrose in water.

Acetazolamide is not used for alkalinisation of urine as it can promote acidemia (option a).

Ascorbic acid causes acidification of urine (option b).

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiency results form isoniazid use ?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid interferes with the production of active co-enzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine and increases the renal excretion of pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

Pyridoxine deficiency leads to peripheral neuritis and other neurological manifestations like paresthesias, numbness and CNS effects.

questions.text: Beta-lactamase inhibitor that does not cause suicidal inhibition of beta-lactamase is
questions.solution:
Avibactam is a newer non-beta lactam beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is a non-suicidal inhibitor. Causes reversible acylation of beta-lactamase targets. Has a broader spectrum of action than suicidal inhibitors. Vaborbactam is another non-suicidal inhibitor.

Suicidal inhibitors

  • Clavulanic acid
  • Tazobactam
  • Sulbactam

questions.text: The following topical antifungal agent acts by chelating trivalent metal cations in fungal cell
questions.solution:
Ciclopirox chelates trivalent metal cations and thereby inhibits metal dependent enzymes required for degradation of peroxides within fungal cell.

Clotrimazole is a topical imidazole that interferes in ergosterol synthesis (option a).

Terbinafine and butenafine are allylamines that interferes in ergosterol synthesis (options c and d).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor ?
questions.solution:
Crizotinib is a ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase) tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is indicated in ALK positive non-small cell lung cancer. BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors

  • Imatinib
  • Nilotinib
  • Dasatinib
  • Ponatinib
  • Bosutinib

questions.text: All are adverse effects of thalidomide except
questions.solution:
Constipation and sedation are common adverse effects of thalidomide. Teratogenicity like phocomelia is seen with thalidomide use in pregnancy that had lead to its withdrawal from market (option c).

Thromboembolic events and hypothyroidism is associated with thalidomide use (options a and d).

questions.text: All are alkylating antineoplastic agents except:
questions.solution:
Capecitabine, the prodrug of 5-FU, is a pyrimidine antagonist and is an antimetabolite.

 Alkylating agents are:

1) Nitrogen mustards

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Ifosfamide
  • Mechlorethamine
  • Melphalan
  • Chlorambucil

2) Nitrosoureas

  • Carmustine
  • Lomustine
  • Semustine
  • Streptozocin

3) Triazines

  • Dacarbazine
  • Temozolomide

4) Methylhydrazine

  • Procarbazine

5) Alkyl sulfonates

  • Busulfan

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding vinblastine ?

choices.text: Component of standard regimen for Hodgkin lymphoma
It is a cell cycle specific agent

questions.solution:
Vinblastine is associated with mild neurotoxicity. Severe myelosuppression is a common issue with vinblastine. Vincristine is commonly associated with severe neurotoxicity.

Vinblastine is the component of standard ABVD regimen in Hodgkin lymphoma (option b).

Vinblastine belongs to vinca alkaloids class that is cell cycle specific agents (options a and d).

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in amitriptyline overdose ?
questions.solution:
Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline are competitive antagonists of muscarinic receptors. Atropine being an antimuscarinic drug should not be administered.

Tricyclic antidepressants overdose:

Presentation

  • Anticholinergic effects
  • Hypotension (alpha 1 receptor blockade)
  • Cardiac depressant effects: quinidine like effects on Na+ channel resulting in slowed conduction and depressed cardiac contractility and result in serious arrhythmias
  • Seizures and agitation followed by depression Management
  • General supportive care that includes gastric lavage (option a)
  • Hypotension is managed by IV fluids and norepinephrine infusion
  • Cardiac depressant effects: bolus dose of sodium bicarbonate helps overcome Na+ blockade by increasing extracellular Na+. Sodium bicarbonate also addresses the metabolic acidosis which is commonly present (option b)
  • Arrhythmias: lignocaine for ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Seizures: benzodiazpeines like diazepam/lorazepam (option d)

Clinical contraindication: Physostigmine can reverse anticholinergic effects but can aggravate cardiac depression and cause seizures. Therefore physostigmine is not indicated.

questions.text: The dose-response curve is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B.  What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.

In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

In competitive agonism, the curve shifts to the left.

In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor, also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text: Adenosine (P1) receptors on the cell surface are of the following type
questions.solution:
Purinergic receptors on cell surface

Adenosine receptors

  • P1: G-protein coupled receptors

ATP receptors

  • P2X: Ligand-gated ion channels
  • P2Y: G-protein coupled receptors

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug?
questions.solution:
In the present case, the volume of distribution of the drug is 6L/kg (420 L in a normal adult with reference weight 70kg) which is very high when compared to the total body water of 42L. Therefore, it can be implied that the drug is having high sequestration in tissues.

The apparent volume of distribution (Vd) is an imaginary volume throughout which the drug is distributed if the plasma concentration remains constant throughout. 

Vd = Dose administered IV/ plasma concentration

The difference in the volume of distribution based on drug type:

  • Low Vd 
    • Restricted to the intravascular compartment 
    • Seen in drugs with high molecular weight (e.g., heparin) or high protein binding (e.g., warfarin - 9.8L)
  • Medium Vd 
    • Lipid insoluble drugs (e.g., gentamicin - 20L) do not enter the cells and are distributed in the extracellular fluid volume
    • Small water-soluble molecules (e.g., ethanol - 42L) are distributed in the total body water
  • High Vd
    • Sequestered and accumulated in the tissues
    • Small lipophilic molecules (e.g., chloroquine - 13000L)
